awd_titl_txt: CIF:Small: Design and Analysis of Spatially-Coupled Coding Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The storage and transmission of digital information is now ubiquitous in our society and plays a valuable role in the modern information-technology infrastructure.  Error-correcting codes are a key part of infrastructure components that efficiently and reliably store and transmit digital information.  Spatial coupling is a new technique for designing error-correcting codes that has been shown in some cases to achieve near-optimal performance with low-complexity decoding.  This research focuses on the design and analysis of innovative techniques for the storage and transmission of digital information based on spatially-coupled codes.

The research is broken into three broad thrusts.  The first thrust focuses on generalizing recent proof techniques for spatially-coupled codes to include a wide class of inference problems on spatially-coupled graphical models.  The second thrust considers the design of universal spatially-coupled codes for multiuser communication problems including the noisy Slepian-Wolf problem and multiple-access communication.  The third thrust targets source and channel coding problems with side information and focuses on nested spatially-coupled codes with enhanced message-passing decoding.

Spatial coupling also appears to be a general principle that is broadly applicable to problems involving message passing and inference on factor graphs. Therefore, this research is expected to have an impact on science and engineering disciplines beyond communications such as signal processing and machine learning.

por.por_cntn:
The storage and transmission of digital information is now ubiquitous in our society and plays a valuable role in the modern information-technology infrastructure. Error-correcting codes are a key part of infrastructure components that efficiently and reliably store and transmit digital information. Spatial coupling is a new technique for designing error-correcting codes that has been shown in some cases to achieve near-optimal performance with low-complexity decoding. This intellectual merit of the research focuses on the design and analysis of innovative techniques for the storage and transmission of digital information based on spatially-coupled codes. Specifically, the outcomes and findings from this project advance the state of the art in the design of several multi-user communication scenarios such as what is encountered in cellular communications and in the design of data storage systems such as flash memories.


Wireless communication systems are prone to interference from multiple users attempting to use the wireless channel at the same time and in the same frequency band. Interference has been traditionally viewed as a nuisance that has to be avoided. However, in the past few years, it has been recognized that it is more efficient to harness the interference instead of avoiding it and one particular approach to harnessing interference is through the use of codes called lattice codes. The findings from this project show how to construct highly effective lattice codes that are also computationally less complex to decode than what is available in the literature.


Recently, there has been a lot of interest in the design multiple access schemes for networks such as the Internet of Things where a massive number of devices operate in an uncoordinated fashion and try to communicate a small amount of information to an access point. An interesting connection has been established between codes on graphs and the decoding of multiple users (or, collision resolution in multiple access schemes) and leveraging this connection, many results from coding theory have been used to design and analyze multiple access schemes. Particularly, it has been shown in the limit of the number of users becoming asymptotically large and for idealized channel models, the throughput efficiency of uncoordinated multiple access can be as high as that of coordinated multiple access. These schemes, however, required knowledge of the number of users at the transmitters. Our findings from this project show how to design effective multiple access schemes when the number of users is not known and for the more practical case of using additive white Gaussian noise channels.


In a typical NAND flash storage system, each cell carries an electric charge that indicates the stored bit; a higher charge denotes a 1 and a lower charge denotes a 0. While raising the charge of these cells can be done easily, lowering the charge requires resetting the whole block of cells. Write once memory (WOM) systems model such storage cells. That is, in a WOM system, after a codeword is written to the storage system, during the next write process, data can be written only in the positions where the previous codeword contained zeros. Recently, there has been a lot of interest in the design of WOM codes. However, most of these constructions do not handle the case when the read process is noisy very well. Our findings from this project show how to construct low-complexity capacity-achieving codes for the binary WOM system which can also handle errors during the read process. 


In some multi-terminal communication problems, side information is available at the receiver about the information that is being communicated or side information is available at the transmitter about the interference that occurs in the channel.  The design of iteratively decodable or encodable codes that can effectively communicate in the presence of such side information has been an unsolved problem. In this project, we empirically showed that spatially coupled compound low-density generator/low-density parity check codes when combined with a belief propagation algorithm and guided decimation can perform very close to the theoretical limits.


Finally, we considered the problem of designing sensing matrices for recovering sparse vectors from observations which are linear combinations of the components of the vector, also known as the compressed sensing problem. By building on the earlier work of other researchers, we designed near-optimal linear combinations.


In order to ensure that research has a broad impact, the findings from this project were published in 8 conference papers and 1 journal paper. Two other journal papers will be submitted soon. The principal investigator also gave tutorials, seminars, and presentations at conferences to disseminate the findings. This project contributed to workforce development by training graduate students who are currently employed in tech companies in the USA. The investigator taught a graduate-level course on probabilistic graphical models and the video lectures from this course are available publicly on the investigator's website.
